content:
I am using a MacOS Sequoia 15 with the VS Code installation of Lean. I often observe that if I leave my laptop with a Lean project open for a while (no specific duration, but the screen locks) and come back, Lean starts complaining about the imports, which I infer from the error messages to be because Lean thinks the directory simply doesn't exist. Closing and reopening Lean fixes the issue everytime.

It doesn't cause me any major inconvenience yet, but why does it happen and is it avoidable?
Do you see an actual error when this happens (red squiggly) or just an information diagnostic (blue squiggly)?
Also, the exact message and how it causes things to fail would be useful.

I would post it, but I realised while posting this here that I should've taken a screenshot before restarting. I'm just waiting for the error to occur again.

And yes, red squiggly.

image.png
Here is the error message. Took very long to come back.

As usual, closing and opening VS Code fixed it. One theory I have is that my external SSD connection is just a little bit loose, and once VS Code decides for a second that the directory is no more, I cannot fix the problem by just refitting the SSD properly. I just want to be sure that that's really all that is happening.
Never use external drives... :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
It seems like that's the cause. Is your SSD connected directly to your computer or through your monitor?

Directly through my laptop. But I think the junction is a bit loose regardless...
Anyway, before this becomes a non-Lean question, I just wanted to check that this is indeed a plausible answer.

Definitely is! If you delete a directory and re-create it at the same location, programs using the "old" directory now have dangling file descriptors (i.e., they don't suddenly point to the "new" directory just because the path is the same). I assume the same happens for mounts.
Aatman Supkar has marked this topic as resolved.
